Race and gender influence most of the sexual harassment that women of color face. Women of color are less likely to report sexual harassment if the perpetrator is the same race. This is known as the code of silence. This is influenced by the race of the harasser, and predominately affects women of color.<ref name="Richardson-2009">{{Cite journal |last1=Richardson |first1=Brian K. |last2=Taylor |first2=Juandalynn |date=2009-08-04 |title=Sexual Harassment at the Intersection of Race and Gender: A Theoretical Model of the Sexual Harassment Experiences of Women of Color |url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/10570310903082065 |journal=Western Journal of Communication |language=en |volume=73 |issue=3 |pages=248–272 |doi=10.1080/10570310903082065 |s2cid=143660626 |issn=1057-0314}}</ref> Black women do not usually see things that a white woman would claim to be sexual harassment because they are accustomed to it, it is normal to them and so there is not much of a problem.<ref name="Welsh-2006"/>
Something that is unique to the sexual harassment of women of color is the common bond factor. The common bond factor is when a man of color sees someone of their own race or culture, and they feel as if it is okay to sexually harass them. They think that they can act and talk without regard to the law because they feel as if it is not being broken.<ref name="Richardson-2009"/>
The perception of sexual harassment from women of color includes racism and sexism whereas white women's perception only includes sexism. There is this interlocking of relations, commonly known as [[intersectionality]], within the sexual harassment women of color face, between racism and sexism. White women, when speaking about sexual harassment, speak from the role of a victim whereas women of color speak from the role of a harasser. Women of color, as well, have stereotypes taken into consideration when it comes to harassment. These stereotypes make it difficult for women of color to come forward about sexual harassment, as they will likely not be believed.<ref name="Richardson-2009"/> For instance, there is the stereotype that Latin women are super emotional and tend to overreact. This stereotype may be conveyed when a Latin woman comes forward about sexual harassment, resulting in her claim not being taken seriously. Speaking up results in stereotypes being put on the person coming forward, making them uncomfortable with doing so.<ref name="Richardson-2009" /> Similarly, it is difficult for women of color to be supported when speaking out, as their experiences are different from those of white women, as is the case of Anita Hill.<ref name="Pantheon Books-1992">{{Cite book |url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/25632335 |title=Race-ing justice, en-gendering power : essays on Anita Hill, Clarence Thomas, and the construction of social reality |date=1992 |publisher=Pantheon Books |others=Toni Morrison |isbn=0-679-74145-3 |edition=1 |location=New York |oclc=25632335}}</ref> Particularly, the feminist movement is geared towards helping white women rather than women of color due to women of color's experiences being foreign. In turn, women of color do not join feminist movements or groups because they do not see their experiences reflected.<ref name="Pantheon Books-1992" />
There is a relationship between legal status and sexual harassment; there is an [[intersectionality]] between them. Citizen status can influence women experiencing or reporting sexual harassment. Being undocumented can make it difficult to come forward for fear of being deported.<ref name="Welsh-2006"/> White women with citizenship say that sexual harassment is unwanted behavior, women of color without citizenship found it difficult to explain what they thought sexual harassment was, but that it did include race.<ref name="Welsh-2006" /> This however makes it difficult for Black women to differentiate sexual harassment in the workplace from sexual harassment in society.<ref name="Welsh-2006" />
==Organizational policies and procedures== Most companies have policies against sexual harassment; however, these policies are not designed and should not attempt to "regulate romance" which goes against human urges.<ref name="markschickman" />
Act upon a report of harassment inside the organization should be: {{blockquote|The investigation should be designed to obtain a prompt and thorough collection of the facts, an appropriate responsive action, and an expeditious report to the complainant that the investigation has been concluded, and, to the full extent appropriate, the action taken.|Mark I. Schickman, Sexual Harassment. The employer's role in prevention. [[American Bar Association]]<ref name="markschickman">{{cite journal|last=Schickman|first=Mark I|title=Sexual Harassment – The employer's role in prevention|journal=The Compleat Lawyer|date=1996|volume=13|issue=1|pages=24–28|publisher=[[American Bar Association]]|url=https://heinonline.org/HOL/LandingPage?handle=hein.journals/gpsolo13&div=11&id=&page=|access-date=11 February 2020}}</ref>|title=|source=}}
When organizations do not take the respective satisfactory measures for properly investigating, stress and psychological counseling and guidance, and just deciding of the problem this could lead to: * Decreased productivity and increased team conflict * Decreased study or job satisfaction * Loss of students and staff. Loss of students who leave school and staff resignations to avoid harassment. Resignations and firings of alleged harassers. * Decreased productivity and increased absenteeism by staff or students experiencing harassment * Decrease in success at meeting academic and financial goals * Increased health-care and sick-pay costs because of the health consequences of harassment or retaliation * The knowledge that harassment is permitted can undermine ethical standards and discipline in the organization in general, as staff or students lose respect for, and trust in, their seniors who indulge in, or turn a blind eye to, or treat improperly sexual harassment * If the problem is ignored or not treated properly, a company's or school's image can suffer * High jury awards for the employee, attorney fees and litigation costs if the problem is ignored or not treated properly (in case of firing the victim) when the complainants are advised to and take the issue to court.<ref name="techrep" /><ref name="VAW_effects" /><ref name="ILO--2002" /><ref>Boland, 1990{{page needed|date=October 2012}}</ref><ref name="janaraver" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://qnc.queensu.ca/story_loader.php?id=42b98262192e9|title=Sexual harassment bad for victims and for business|date=June 22, 2005|website=Queen's News Centre|publisher=Queen's University School of Business|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090907233138/http://qnc.queensu.ca/story_loader.php?id=42b98262192e9|archive-date=September 7, 2009|access-date=March 13, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.westerncape.gov.za/eng/pubs/guides/S/63925/7|title=For Help with the Handling of Harassment|last=Prekel|first=Truida|date=2005|publisher=Western Cape Government|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018012030/http://www.westerncape.gov.za/eng/pubs/guides/S/63925/7|archive-date=2012-10-18|access-date=2012-10-07}}</ref>
Studies show that [[organizational climate]] (an organization's tolerance, policy, procedure etc.) and workplace environment are essential for understanding the conditions in which sexual harassment is likely to occur, and the way its victims will be affected (yet, research on specific policy and procedure, and awareness strategies is lacking). Another element which increases the risk for sexual harassment is the job's gender context (having few women in the close working environment or practicing in a field which is perceived as atypical for women).<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1744-6570.2007.00067.x |title=A Meta-Analysis of the Antecedents and Consequences of Workplace Sexual Harassment |year=2007 |last1=Willness |first1=Chelsea R. |last2=Steel |first2=Piers |last3=Lee |first3=Kibeom |journal=Personnel Psychology |volume=60 |pages=127–162 |citeseerx=10.1.1.472.6532 }}</ref>
Although research on occupational sexual assault is still in its infancy, the European Union reports that 40–50% of women report having encountered inappropriate sexual conduct or sexual harassment at work (World Health Organization, 2012). According to Burn (2018), In order to reduce sexual harassment, organisational climates and circumstances that support sexual harassment must change. Changes to the normative environments that sustain sexual harassment include the adoption of explicit anti-harassment rules and practices. Sexual harassment rules have the potential to deter sexual harassment and provide victims with channels for redress. According to Medeiros (2019),<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Medeiros |first1=Kelsey |last2=Griffith |first2=Jennifer |date=March 2019 |title=#Ustoo: How I-O psychologists can extend the conversation on sexual harassment and sexual assault through workplace training |url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/industrial-and-organizational-psychology/article/abs/ustoo-how-io-psychologists-can-extend-the-conversation-on-sexual-harassment-and-sexual-assault-through-workplace-training/634BE392AA182B153850A1B2452380AB |journal=Industrial and Organizational Psychology |language=en |volume=12 |issue=1 |pages=1–19 |doi=10.1017/iop.2018.155 |issn=1754-9426}}</ref> the current endeavour puts out a framework for creating workplace sexual harassment prevention programmes and is based on research on training and development, college sexual assault, and workplace sexual harassment. The suggestions for preventing sexual harassment are mostly based on the research on sexual assault on college campuses. The persistent curiosity in and study of educational institutions for sexual assault preventative measures, despite this approach's shortcomings, has produced a database of researched interventions that fills in the gaps left by the dearth of empirical studies on sexual assault preventive interventions. Additionally, sexual harassment and assault have been characterised as a continuum where less severe behaviours have the potential to escalate into more violent acts over time if left unchecked (Department of Defence, 2014; Fitzgerald,1993). Hence, even if sexual harassment and assault are distinct behavior's, their increasing prevalence indicates that interventions ought to address the entire range of behaviors', particularly considering the restricted time and financial resources allocated to educational programms.
According to Dr. Orit Kamir, the most effective way to avoid sexual harassment in the workplace, and also influence the public's state of mind, is for the employer to adopt a clear policy prohibiting sexual harassment and to make it very clear to their employees. Many women prefer to make a complaint and to have the matter resolved within the workplace rather than to "air out the dirty laundry" with a public complaint and be seen as a traitor by colleagues, superiors and employers, adds Kamir.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://portal.idc.ac.il/he/lawreview/volumes/volume09/pages/kamir.aspx|last=Orit|first=Kamir|date=2008|website=IDC Herzliya|language=he, en|script-title=he:החוק הישראלי למניעת הטרדה מינית — איפה אנחנו במלאת לו עשור?|trans-title=Israel's Sexual Harassment Law After Its First Decade: An Assessment of Its Achievements and Failings|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121202032950/http://portal.idc.ac.il/He/lawreview/volumes/volume09/Pages/kamir.aspx|archive-date=2012-12-02|access-date=2020-02-11}}</ref><ref name="maryrowe">Rowe, Mary. [http://web.mit.edu/ombud/publications/deal.pdf "Dealing with Harassment: A Systems Approach,"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121106173032/http://web.mit.edu/ombud/publications/deal.pdf |date=2012-11-06 }} in ''Sexual Harassment: Perspectives, Frontiers, and Response Strategies, Women & Work, Vol. 5''. Sage Publications, 1996, pp. 241–271. {{ISBN|978-0-8039-5794-7}}.{{page needed|date=December 2013}}</ref><ref name="DoiBFMissing">{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/BF01000611 |title=People who feel harassed need a complaint system with both formal and informal options |year=1990 |last1=Rowe |first1=Mary P. |journal=Negotiation Journal |volume=6 |issue=2 |pages=161–172|s2cid=145016770 }}</ref>
Most prefer a pragmatic solution that would stop the harassment and prevent future contact with the harasser rather than turning to the police. More about the difficulty in turning an offense into a legal act can be found in Felstiner & Sarat's (1981) study,<ref>{{cite journal |first1=William L.F. |last1=Felstiner |first2=Richard L. |last2=Abel |first3=Austin |last3=Sarat |year=1980 |title=The Emergence and Transformation of Disputes: Naming, Blaming, Claiming… |journal=Law & Society Review |volume=15 |issue=3/4 |pages=631–54 |jstor=3053505 |doi=10.2307/3053505|s2cid=56047694 }}</ref> which describes three steps a victim (of any dispute) must go through before turning to the justice system: naming—giving the assault a definition, blaming—understanding who is responsible for the violation of rights and facing them, and finally, claiming—turning to the authorities.
==Evolution of law in different jurisdictions== It may include a range of actions from mild transgressions to [[sexual abuse]] or [[sexual assault]].<ref name="auto" /> Sexual harassment is a form of [[Law|illegal]] [[employment discrimination]] in many countries, and is a form of [[abuse]] (sexual and [[psychological abuse]]s) and [[bullying]].
The [[Declaration on the Elimination of Violence Against Women]] classifies [[violence against women]] into three categories: that occurring in the family, that occurring within the general community, and that perpetrated or condoned by the State. The term ''sexual harassment'' is used in defining violence occurring in the general community, which is defined as: "Physical, sexual and psychological violence occurring within the general community, including rape, sexual abuse, sexual harassment and intimidation at work, in educational institutions and elsewhere, trafficking in women and forced prostitution."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/en/genocideprevention/documents/atrocity-crimes/Doc.21_declaration%20elimination%20vaw.pdf|title=Declaration on the Elimination of Violence against Women|last=United Nations General Assembly|date=20 December 1993|work=United Nations|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190214081113/http://www.un.org/en/genocideprevention/documents/atrocity-crimes/Doc.21_declaration%20elimination%20vaw.pdf|archive-date=14 February 2019}}</ref>
Sexual harassment is subject to a [[Directive (European Union)|directive in the European Union]].<ref name="eur-lex.europa.eu">[http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CONSLEG:1976L0207:20021005:EN:PDF "{O}n the implementation of the principle of equal treatment for men and women ... (76/207/EEC)"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140204010321/http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CONSLEG:1976L0207:20021005:EN:PDF |date=2014-02-04 }}, Council of the [[European Communities|European Economic Communities]], 9 February 1976. Amended 23 September 2002.</ref> The [[United States]]' [[Equal Employment Opportunity Commission]] (EEOC) states, "It is unlawful to harass a person (an applicant or employee) because of that person's sex."
In India, the case of ''[[Vishakha and others v State of Rajasthan]]'' in 1997 has been credited with establishing sexual harassment as illegal.<ref name="india_rape">{{cite web|url=http://www.legalserviceindia.com/articles/rape_laws.htm|title=Redefining the Rape laws in India: a constructive and comparative approach|last=Desal|first=Dhruv|date=30 December 2003|publisher=Legal Service India|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130115194231/http://www.legalserviceindia.com/articles/rape_laws.htm|archive-date=15 January 2013|access-date=2012-10-07}}</ref> In Israel, the 1988 Equal Employment Opportunity Law made it a crime for an employer to retaliate against an employee who had rejected sexual advances, but it was not until 1998 that the Israeli Sexual Harassment Law made such behavior illegal.<ref name="Kamir" />
In May 2002, the [[European Union]] Council and Parliament amended a 1976 Council Directive on the equal treatment of men and women in employment to prohibit sexual harassment in the workplace, naming it a form of sex discrimination and violation of dignity. This Directive required all Member States of the European Union to adopt laws on sexual harassment, or amend existing laws to comply with the Directive by October 2005.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stopvaw.org/Domestic_Legal_Framework.html?Type=B_BASIC&SEC=%7BD7FABC81-256E-41C1-BF3A-563AD89AA809%7D|title=Domestic Legal Framework|last=Stop Violence Against Women|date=13 July 2007|publisher=The Advocates for Human Rights|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181116004349/http://www.stopvaw.org/Domestic_Legal_Framework.html?Type=B_BASIC&SEC=%7BD7FABC81-256E-41C1-BF3A-563AD89AA809%7D|archive-date=16 November 2018|access-date=2020-02-11}}</ref>
In 2005, China added new provisions to the ''Law on Women's Right Protection'' to include sexual harassment.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/4625913.stm |title=China to outlaw sexual harassment |work=BBC News |date=27 June 2005 |access-date=2012-10-07 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120730155433/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/4625913.stm |archive-date=30 July 2012 |url-status=live }}</ref> In 2006, "The Shanghai Supplement" was drafted to help further define sexual harassment in China.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Li |first1=Cao |last2=South |first2=Mark |url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2006-10/27/content_718147.htm |title=Draft bill details sexual harassment |publisher=China Daily |date=27 October 2006 |access-date=2012-10-07 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121024012122/http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2006-10/27/content_718147.htm |archive-date=24 October 2012 |url-status=live }}</ref>
Sexual harassment was specifically criminalized for the first time in modern Egyptian history in June 2014.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hendawi|first1=Hamza|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/sexual-assault-on-student-sparks-outrage-in-egypt/|title=Sexual assault on student sparks outrage in Egypt Read more: Sexual assault on student sparks outrage in Egypt|date=10 June 2014|work=The Times of Israel|access-date=7 November 2014|url-status=live|agency=Associated Press|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141107120444/http://www.timesofisrael.com/sexual-assault-on-student-sparks-outrage-in-egypt/|archive-date=7 November 2014}}</ref>
{{As of|2016||df=}}, sexual harassment remains legal in Kuwait<ref>{{Cite book|chapter-url=https://www.hrw.org/world-report/2016/country-chapters/kuwait|title=World Report 2016: Kuwait|publisher=[[Human Rights Watch]]|year=2016|chapter=Women's Rights, Sexual Orientation, and Gender Identity|access-date=11 February 2020}}</ref> and Djibouti.<ref>[https://2009-2017.state.gov/documents/organization/252887.pdf "Djibouti 2015 Human Rights Report"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190907015343/https://2009-2017.state.gov/documents/organization/252887.pdf |date=2019-09-07 }}, [[United States Department of State]] [[Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights and Labor]].</ref>
===Varied legal guidelines and definitions=== '''The [[United Nations]] General Recommendation 19 to the convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women''' defines sexual harassment of women to include:
<blockquote>such unwelcome sexually determined behavior as physical contact and advances, sexually colored remarks, showing pornography and sexual demands, whether by words or actions. Such conduct can be humiliating and may constitute a health and safety problem; it is discriminatory when the woman has reasonable ground to believe that her objection would disadvantage her in connection with her employment, including recruitment or promotion, or when it creates a hostile working environment.</blockquote>
While such conduct can be harassment of women by men, many laws around the world which prohibit sexual harassment recognize that both men and women may be harassers or victims of sexual harassment. However, most claims of sexual harassment are made by women.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eeoc.gov/eeoc/statistics/enforcement/sexual_harassment.cfm |title=Sexual Harassment Charges: EEOC & FEPAs Combined: FY 1997 – FY 2011 |publisher=U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission |access-date=2012-10-07 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121007201224/http://www.eeoc.gov/eeoc/statistics/enforcement/sexual_harassment.cfm |archive-date=2012-10-07 |url-status=live }}</ref>
There are many similarities, and also important differences in laws and definitions used around the world.
===Africa=== ====Egypt==== Sexual harassment is rife in Egypt. A 2013 study from the United Nations showed that 99.3 percent of Egyptian women have suffered some form of sexual harassment. Authorities punish women when they do speak out.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/20190722-egypt-15-year-old-girl-detained-for-stabbing-her-rapist/|title=Egypt: 15-year-old girl detained for stabbing her rapist|date=July 22, 2019|website=Middle East Monitor|access-date=November 25, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191212024928/https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/20190722-egypt-15-year-old-girl-detained-for-stabbing-her-rapist/|archive-date=December 12, 2019|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.albawaba.com/node/egyptians-defend-young-girl-killed-her-rapist-face-law-1298118|title=Egyptians Defend Young Girl Who Killed Her Rapist In Face of The Law|date=July 18, 2019|website=Al Bawaba}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/20191106-egypt-girl-who-stabbed-her-rapist-released/|title=Egypt girl who stabbed her rapist released|date=November 6, 2019|website=Middle East Monitor|access-date=November 25, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191107135752/https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/20191106-egypt-girl-who-stabbed-her-rapist-released/|archive-date=November 7, 2019|url-status=live}}</ref>
====Morocco==== In 2016, a stricter law proscribing sexual harassment was proposed in Morocco specifying fines and a possible jail sentence of up to 6 months.<ref name="tmt_24March2016">{{cite news|url=http://themoroccantimes.com/2016/03/18929/sexual-harrassement-morocco-jail-sentence|title=Up to 6 Months in Jail if You Sexually Harass a Woman in Morocco|date=24 March 2016|work=The Moroccan Times|access-date=11 October 2016|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161011143631/http://themoroccantimes.com/2016/03/18929/sexual-harrassement-morocco-jail-sentence|archive-date=11 October 2016}}</ref> The existing law against harassment was reported to not be upheld, as harassment was not reported to police by victims and even when reported, was not investigated by police or prosecuted by the courts.<ref name="tmt_24March2016" /><ref name="bbc_mag_10Oct2016">{{cite news |title=The Moroccan women fighting daily sexual harassment |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-37589687 |access-date=11 October 2016 |work=BBC Magazine |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=10 October 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161010235625/http://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-37589687 |archive-date=10 October 2016 |url-status=live }}</ref> On June 1, 2023, a Moroccan court sentenced a 32-year-old man to two years in prison for sexually harassing and forcibly kissing a woman inside a church.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://themoroccantimes.com/2023/06/25902/man-sentenced-to-two-years-in-jail-for-sexual-harassment-and-kissing-inside-tangier-church|title=Man Sentenced to Two Years in Jail for Sexual Harassment and Kissing Inside Tangier Church|publisher=The Moroccan Times|date=2023-06-03|access-date=2023-06-03}}</ref>
===Australia=== The [[Sex Discrimination Act 1984]] defines sexual harassment as "... a person sexually harasses another person (the person harassed ) if: (a) the person makes an unwelcome sexual advance, or an unwelcome request for sexual favours, to the person harassed; or (b) engages in other unwelcome conduct of a sexual nature in relation to the person harassed; in circumstances in which a reasonable person, having regard to all the circumstances, would have anticipated the possibility that the person harassed would be offended, humiliated or intimidated."<ref>{{cite Legislation AU|Cth|act|sda1984209|Sex Discrimination Act 1984|28A}}.</ref>
===Europe=== In the [[European Union]], there is a [[Directive (European Union)|directive]] on sexual harassment. The ''Directive 2002/73/EC – equal treatment of 23 September 2002 amending Council Directive 76/207/EEC on the implementation of the principle of equal treatment for men and women as regards access to employment, vocational training and promotion, and working conditions'' states:<ref name="eur-lex.europa.eu" /> <blockquote>For the purposes of this Directive, the following definitions shall apply: (...) * sexual harassment: where any form of unwanted verbal, non-verbal or physical conduct of a sexual nature occurs, with the purpose or effect of violating the dignity of a person, in particular when creating an intimidating, hostile, degrading, humiliating or offensive environment Harassment and sexual harassment within the meaning of this Directive shall be deemed to be discrimination on the grounds of sex and therefore prohibited.</blockquote>
The [[Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence]] also addresses the issue of sexual harassment (Article 40), using a similar definition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://conventions.coe.int/Treaty/EN/Treaties/Html/210.htm|title=Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence (CETS No. 210)|last=Council of Europe|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923210455/http://www.conventions.coe.int/Treaty/EN/Treaties/Html/210.htm|archive-date=2015-09-23}}</ref>
====Denmark==== Sexual harassment is defined as, when any verbal, non-verbal or physical action is used to change a victim's sexual status against the will of the victim and resulting in the victim feeling inferior or hurting the victim's dignity. Man and woman are looked upon as equal, and any action trying to change the balance in status with the differences in sex as a tool, is also sexual harassment. In the workplace, jokes, remarks, etc., are only deemed discriminatory if the employer has stated so in their written policy. Law number 1385 of December 21, 2005 regulates this area.<ref name="Denmark law">{{cite web|url=http://www.ku.dk/regel/2/2002.html#LOV%20nr%201385|title=Denmark Law|date=2016-06-29|publisher=Københavns Universitet|language=da|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120321222932/http://www.ku.dk/regel/2/2002.html#LOV%20nr%201385|archive-date=21 March 2012|access-date=2012-10-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.retsinformation.dk/forms/r0710.aspx?id=137042|title=Ligebehandlingsloven – Bekendtgørelse af lov om ligebehandling af mænd og kvinder med hensyn til beskæftigelse m.v|website=www.retsinformation.dk|language=da|trans-title=The Equal Treatment Act – Executive Order on the Equal Treatment Act for men and women with regard to employment, etc.|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181214022811/https://www.retsinformation.dk/Forms/R0710.aspx?id=137042|archive-date=2018-12-14|access-date=2020-02-11}}</ref>
====France==== In [[France]], both the Criminal Code and the Labor Code are relevant to the issue of sexual harassment. Until May 4, 2012, article 222-33 of the French Criminal Code described sexual harassment as "The fact of harassing anyone in order to obtain favors of a sexual nature".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/affichTexte.do?cidTexte=JORFTEXT000000408905|title=Loi n° 2002–73 du 17 janvier 2002 de modernisation sociale|date=17 January 2002|website=Legifrance|language=fr|trans-title=Art. 179 of the Law no. 2002-73 of 17 January 2002 on social modernization|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180207182819/https://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/affichTexte.do?cidTexte=JORFTEXT000000408905|archive-date=2018-02-07|access-date=11 February 2020}}</ref> Since 2002, it recognized the possibility of sexual harassment between co-workers and not only by supervisors. On May 4, 2012, the [[Constitutional Council (France)|Supreme Court of France]] quashed the definition of the criminal code as being too vague.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.conseil-constitutionnel.fr/en/decision/2012/2012240QPC.htm|title=Decision no. 2012-240 QPC of May 4, 2012|website=Conseil constitutionnel|language=en|access-date=2020-02-11|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190602055255/https://www.conseil-constitutionnel.fr/en/decision/2012/2012240QPC.htm|archive-date=June 2, 2019|url-status=live}}</ref> The 2012 decision resulted from a law on priority preliminary rulings on the issue of constitutionality. As a consequence of this decision, all pending procedures before criminal courts were cancelled. Several feminist NGOs, such as AFVT, criticized this decision. President [[François Hollande]], the Minister of Justice (Christine Taubira) and the Minister of Equality (Najat Belkacem) asked that a new law be voted rapidly. As a result, ''LOI n°2012-954 du 6 août 2012'' was voted in, providing a new definition.<ref>[http://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/affichCodeArticle.do?idArticle=LEGIARTI000021796942&cidTexte=LEGITEXT000006070719 "Code pénal: Article 222-33" (in French)] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612163504/https://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/affichCodeArticle.do?idArticle=LEGIARTI000021796942&cidTexte=LEGITEXT000006070719 |date=2018-06-12 }}, ''legifrance.gouv.fr''.</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fonction-publique.gouv.fr/loi-6-aout-2012-relative-au-harcelement-sexuel|title=Loi du 6 août 2012 relative au harcèlement sexuel|date=20 2019|access-date=2020-02-11}}</ref> In addition to criminal provisions, the French Labor code also prohibits sexual harassment.<ref>Act of 2 November 1992</ref> The legislator voted a law in 2008<ref>Act of 27 May 2008</ref> that copied the 2002/73/EC Directive<ref>Directive of 23 September 2002 amending Council Directive 76/207/EEC on the implementation of the principle of equal treatment for men and women as regards access to employment, vocational training and promotion, and working conditions</ref><ref>{{Citation|title=Directive 2002/73/EC of the European Parliament and of definition without modifying the French Labour Code.
According to Abigail C. Saguy in her book ''What is Sexual Harassment: From Capitol Hill to the Sorbonne'', "According to French penal law, '''sexual''' '''harassment''' is also different from rape and sexual assault in that it does not involve physical contact. Rather, with '''sexual harassment''', economic dependence and official authority alone are used to pressure a person into having sexual relations(pg.24)."
====Germany==== [[File:1833 Neder Im Gasthof anagoria.JPG|thumb|''At the Tavern'', by Johann Michael Neder, 1833, [[Germanisches Nationalmuseum]]]] In June 2016, the governing coalition decided about the key points of a tightening of the law governing sexual offenses (Sexualstrafrecht, literally: law on the punishment of sexual delicts). On July 7, 2016, the Bundestag passed the resolution<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/bundestag-beschliesst-neues-sexualstrafrecht-a-1101813.html|title=Votum: Bundestag beschließt neues Sexualstrafrecht|date=2016-07-07|journal=Spiegel Online|access-date=2016-07-07|url-status=live|language=de|trans-title=Vote: Bundestag passes new sexual criminal law|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160707120628/http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/bundestag-beschliesst-neues-sexualstrafrecht-a-1101813.html|archive-date=2016-07-07}}</ref> and by fall of that year, the draft bill will be presented to the second chamber, the Bundesrat.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/sexualstrafrecht-alles-was-sie-zu-nein-heisst-nein-wissen-muessen-a-1101658.html|title=Neues Sexualstrafrecht: Nein heißt Nein. Und was bedeutet das jetzt?|date=2016-07-07|journal=Spiegel Online|access-date=2016-07-07|url-status=live|language=de|trans-title=New Sexual Criminal Law: No means No. And what does that mean now?|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180120202657/http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/sexualstrafrecht-alles-was-sie-zu-nein-heisst-nein-wissen-muessen-a-1101658.html|archive-date=2018-01-20}}</ref> By this change, sexual harassment shall become punishable under the ''Sexualstrafrecht''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dw.com/de/nein-hei%C3%9Ft-nein-koalition-reformiert-sexualstrafrecht/a-19336217|title='Nein heißt Nein' – Koalition reformiert Sexualstrafrecht|date=2016-06-16|publisher=Deutsche Welle|language=de|trans-title="No means No" – coalition reforms sexual criminal law|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160617135723/http://www.dw.com/de/nein-hei%C3%9Ft-nein-koalition-reformiert-sexualstrafrecht/a-19336217|archive-date=2016-06-17|access-date=2016-06-18}}</ref>
Now sexual harassment is punishable by law according to § 184i of the law governing sexual offenses. The law only states unwanted physical contact as sexual haressment but has been extended in 2020 to include "cybergrooming" as well.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://dejure.org/gesetze/StGB/184i.html|title=Sexuelle Belästigung|access-date=2020-07-10|website=dejure.org}}</ref>
====Greece==== In response to the EU Directive 2002/73/EC, [[Greece]] enacted Law 3488/2006 (O.G.A.'.191).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://evaw-global-database.unwomen.org/en/countries/europe/greece/2006/law-3488-2006-on-the-implementation-of-the-principle-of-equal-treatment-of-men-and-women|title=Law 3488/2006: Framework on Equal Treatment of Men and Women|website=Global Database on Violence against Women|publisher=[[United Nations Entity for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women|UN Women]]|access-date=2020-02-11}}</ref> The law specifies that sexual harassment is a form of gender-based discrimination in the workplace. Victims also have the right to compensation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sgdatabase.unwomen.org/searchDetail.action?measureId%3D10297%26baseHREF%3Dcountry%26baseHREFId%3D563|title=LAW 3488/2006 ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PRINCIPLE OF EQUAL TREATMENT OF MEN AND WOMEN IN THE FIELDS OF ACCESS TO EMPLOYMENT, VOCATIONAL TRAINING AND PROMOTION, TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF WORK|date=7 September 2009|website=The UN Secretary-General's database on violaence against women|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201171917/http://sgdatabase.unwomen.org/searchDetail.action?measureId=10297&baseHREF=country&baseHREFId=563|archive-date=2014-02-01|access-date=2014-01-24}}</ref> Prior to this law, the policy on sexual harassment in Greece was very weak. Sexual harassment was not defined by any law, and victims could only use general laws, which were very poor in addressing the issue.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://digitalcommons.wcl.american.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1408&context=hrbrief|title=The New European Union Directive on Sexual Harassment and Its Implications for Greece|last=Tsekos|first=Mary Ellen|date=2003|website=Human Rights Brief|publisher=Center for Human Rights & Humanitarian Law|access-date=11 February 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.intellectum.org/articles/issues/intellectum3/en/ITL03p015025_Sexual%20Harassment%20in%20the%20Greek%20Criminal%20Law_Elissavet%20Symeonidou%20Kastanidou.pdf|title=The Sexual Harassment in Greek Criminal Law (Law 3488/2006)|last=Symeonidou-Kastanidou|first=E.|date=30 May 2007|website=Intellectum|others=Translated by Victor Tsilonis and Danai Roussou|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202101821/http://www.intellectum.org/articles/issues/intellectum3/en/ITL03p015025_Sexual%20Harassment%20in%20the%20Greek%20Criminal%20Law_Elissavet%20Symeonidou%20Kastanidou.pdf|archive-date=2 February 2014|access-date=2 February 2014}}</ref>
====Russia==== In the Criminal Code, Russian Federation, (CC RF), there exists a law which prohibits utilization of an office position and material dependence for coercion of sexual interactions (Article 118, current CC Mistake, not 118, but - [https://www.consultant.ru/document/cons%20doc%20LAW%2010699/ articles 132, 133]). However, according to the Moscow Center for Gender Studies, in practice, the courts do not examine these issues.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://shsf.invisionzone.com/index.php?s=a1f5e83af0f492d74310d4d1a073b792&showtopic=279|title=Sexual Harassment in Russian Workplaces|last=Khotkina|first=Dr. Zoya|date=25 April 1997|publisher=Moscow Centre for Gender Studies|via=Sexual Harassment Support Forum|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070311060132/http://shsf.invisionzone.com/index.php?s=a1f5e83af0f492d74310d4d1a073b792&showtopic=279|archive-date=2007-03-11}}</ref>
In 2008, ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' quoted a survey in which "100 percent of female professionals [in Russia] said they had been subjected to sexual harassment by their bosses, 32 per cent said they had had intercourse with them at least once and another seven per cent claimed to have been raped."<ref>{{cite news |url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/russia/2470310/Sexual-harrassment-okay-as-it-ensures-humans-breed-Russian-judge-rules.html |title = Sexual harassment okay as it ensures humans breed, Russian judge rules |last = Blomfield |first = Adrian |date = 29 Jul 2008 |newspaper = The Daily Telegraph |access-date = 15 July 2011 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110711120823/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/russia/2470310/Sexual-harrassment-okay-as-it-ensures-humans-breed-Russian-judge-rules.html |archive-date = 11 July 2011 |url-status = live }}</ref>
====Switzerland==== A ban on discrimination was included in the Federal Constitution (Article 4, Paragraph 2 of the old Federal Constitution) in 1981 and adopted in Article 8, paragraph 2 of the revised Constitution. The ban on sexual harassment in the workplace forms part of the Federal Act on Gender Equality (GEA) of 24 March 1995, where it is one of several provisions which prohibit discrimination in employment and which are intended to promote equality. Article 4 of the GEA defines the circumstances, Article 5 legal rights and Article 10 protection against dismissal during the complaints procedure.<ref name="Swiss.gov-2017">{{cite web|url=https://www.admin.ch/opc/en/classified-compilation/19950082/index.html|title=Federal Act on Gender Equality|date=1 January 2017|website=The Federal Council – The Portal of the Swiss Government|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180324102217/https://www.admin.ch/opc/en/classified-compilation/19950082/index.html|archive-date=24 March 2018|access-date=2018-03-23}}</ref> Article 328, paragraph 1 of the Code of Obligations (OR), Article 198 (2) of the Penal Code (StGB) and Article 6, paragraph 1 of the Employment Act (ArG) contain further statutory provisions on the ban on sexual harassment. The ban on sexual harassment is intended exclusively for employers, within the scope of their responsibility for protection of legal personality, mental and physical well-being and health.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}}
Article 4 of the GEA of 1995 discusses the topic of sexual harassment in the workplace: "Any harassing behaviour of a sexual nature or other behaviour related to the person's sex that adversely affects the dignity of women or men in the workplace is discriminatory. Such behaviour includes in particular threats, the promise of advantages, the use of coercion and the exertion of pressure in order to obtain favours of a sexual nature."<ref name="Swiss.gov-2017" />
====United Kingdom==== The Discrimination Act of 1975 was modified to establish sexual harassment as a form of discrimination in 1986.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eoc-law.org.uk/default.aspx?page=4666|title=Strathclyde Regional Council v Porcelli [1986] IRLR 134 Court of Session|work=Equal Opportunities Commission|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080408051338/http://www.eoc-law.org.uk/default.aspx?page=4666|archive-date=8 April 2008}}</ref> It states that harassment occurs where there is unwanted conduct on the ground of a person's sex or unwanted conduct of a sexual nature and that conduct has the purpose or effect of violating a person's dignity, or of creating an intimidating, hostile, degrading, humiliating or offensive environment for them. If an employer treats someone less favourably because they have rejected, or submitted to, either form of harassment described above, this is also harassment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eoc.org.uk/Default.aspx?page=15657|title=Sexual Harassment: what the law says|date=2010-08-10|website=Equal Opportunities Commission|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070831002533/http://www.eoc.org.uk/Default.aspx?page=15657|archive-date=August 31, 2007|access-date=2012-10-07}}</ref> In March 2021, a study by UN Women UK found out that 97% of young women 18-24 have experienced some sort of sexual harassment.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2021-03-10 |title=Four-fifths of young women in the UK have been sexually harassed, survey finds |url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/mar/10/almost-all-young-women-in-the-uk-have-been-sexually-harassed-survey-finds |access-date=2022-12-30 |website=The Guardian |language=en}}</ref>
Sexual harassment is also now considered discrimination under [[Equality Act 2010|the Equality Act 2010.]] The Equality Act 2010 merged over 116 separate pieces of legislation under one act that protects the rights of citizens and promotes equality for all people.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.equalityhumanrights.com/en/equality-act-2010/what-equality-act|title=What is the Equality Act? |publisher=Equality and Human Rights Commission|website=www.equalityhumanrights.com|access-date=2020-04-08}}</ref> The new law strengthened the protection of individuals from discrimination in a number of areas. It is designed to protect individuals from discrimination on the basis of age, disability, gender reassignment, marriage and civil partnership, pregnancy and maternity, race, religion or belief, sex, and sexual orientation. It covers a wide range of areas, including employment, education, housing, public accommodations, and the provision of goods and services. Under the Equality Act 2010, it is unlawful to discriminate against someone on the basis of any of these protected characteristics. This includes direct discrimination, indirect discrimination, harassment, and victimization. The Act also places a duty on public authorities, such as local councils and government departments, to consider the impact of their policies and decisions on people who have protected characteristics, and to take steps to promote equality of opportunity and to eliminate discrimination.<ref>Maria Khan, and Ayesha Ahmed, "The protection against harassment of women at the workplace act 2010: A legislative review." ''Lahore University of Management Sciences law Journal'' 3 (2016): 91+ [https://scholar.archive.org/work/os3iqu54obhdxblxehylrico5q/access/wayback/https://sahsol.lums.edu.pk/sites/default/files/harassment_of_women.pdf online].</ref>
Although the 2010 Equality Act is in place, many are pushing the UK government to put even more policies in place to stop sexual harassment in the workplace. One group in particular, "This is Not Working", acts because according to recent surveys done by the Women and Equalities Committee, workplace sexual harassment is still very prevalent, even with the current legislation. The movement pushes for even more employers to take responsibility and proactively prevent sexual harassment.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.natlawreview.com/article/not-working-answer-one-consultation-please-uk|title=This is Not Working – the Answer? One Consultation, Please (UK)|website=The National Law Review|language=en|access-date=2020-04-12}}</ref>
=== Asia === ==== China ==== In [[China]], the 2005 Law for the Protection of Women's Rights and Interests of the People's Republic of China states "sexual harassment against women is prohibited"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cecc.gov/resources/legal-provisions/protection-of-womens-rights-and-interests-law-of-the-peoples-republic-of|title=Protection of Women's Rights and Interests Law of the People's Republic of China (Chinese and English Text)|website=Congressional-Executive Commission on China|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190418130448/https://www.cecc.gov/resources/legal-provisions/protection-of-womens-rights-and-interests-law-of-the-peoples-republic-of|archive-date=2019-04-18|access-date=2019-04-18}}</ref> although the law does not explicitly define what sexual harassment is.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.shrm.org/resourcesandtools/legal-and-compliance/employment-law/pages/global-china-anti-harassment-requirements.aspx|title=China: Time to Review Your Policies Against Sexual Harassment|last1=Ligorner|first1=K. Lesli|last2=Wang|first2=Dora|date=2018-08-24|website=SHRM|language=en-US|access-date=2019-04-18}}</ref>
Sexual harassment is still pervasive within Chinese culture. A 2018 survey of female journalists revealed that 80% had experienced unwanted behavior,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/china/society/article/2142703/why-chinese-women-dont-speak-out-about-sexual-harassment|title=Why sexual harassment in the workplace goes unreported in China|last=Zuo|first=Mandy|date=2018-04-21|website=South China Morning Post|language=en|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190418130448/https://www.scmp.com/news/china/society/article/2142703/why-chinese-women-dont-speak-out-about-sexual-harassment|archive-date=2019-04-18|access-date=2019-04-18}}</ref> and an online survey of college students from all 34 [[Provinces of China|provinces]] the same year revealed that 75% of female students and 35% of male students had experienced sexual harassment.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ucanews.com/news/sexual-harassment-common-on-chinese-campuses/82604|title=Sexual harassment common on Chinese campuses|date=June 20, 2018|website=UCA News|language=en|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190418130448/https://www.ucanews.com/news/sexual-harassment-common-on-chinese-campuses/82604|archive-date=April 18, 2019|access-date=2019-04-18}}</ref>
==== Lebanon ==== As of 2020, it is estimated that one in four women in [[Lebanon]] have been subjected to some form of unsolicited sexual advance, ranging from verbal to physical.<ref name="Yassine-2020">{{Cite web|last=Yassine|first=Hussein|date=21 December 2020|title=Lebanese Parliament Just Voted To Criminalize Sexual Harassment|url=https://www.the961.com/lebanese-parliament-sexual-harassment/|access-date=21 December 2020|website=The961|language=en-US}}</ref> On 21 December 2020, the [[Parliament of Lebanon|Lebanese Parliament]] passed a law criminalizing sexual harassment.<ref name="Yassine-2020" /> There was no national legislation to directly criminalize sexual harassment prior, with draft laws being proposed several times without effect.<ref name="Yassine-2020" />
====India==== {{Further|Sexism in India|Eve teasing|The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013}}
Sexual harassment in [[India]] is termed "[[Eve teasing]]" and is described as: unwelcome sexual gesture or behaviour whether directly or indirectly as sexually colored remarks; physical contact and advances; showing pornography; a demand or request for sexual favours; any other unwelcome physical, verbal or non-verbal conduct being sexual in nature or passing sexually offensive and unacceptable remarks. The critical factor is the unwelcomeness of the behaviour, thereby making the impact of such actions on the recipient more relevant rather than intent of the perpetrator.<ref name="india_rape" /> According to the [[Indian constitution]], sexual harassment infringes the fundamental right of a woman to gender equality under Article 14 and her right to life and live with dignity under Article 21.<ref name="amicus.iupindia.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.amicus.iupindia.org/Lels_WorkplaceHarassment_ovw.asp|title=ICFAI University – Workplace Harassment|website=Amicus.iupindia.org|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171202183755/http://www.amicus.iupindia.org/Lels_WorkplaceHarassment_ovw.asp|archive-date=2017-12-02|access-date=2012-10-07}}</ref><!-- The archives are only of the domain reselling page -->
In 1997, the [[Supreme Court of India]] in a [[Public Interest Litigation]] defined sexual harassment at workplace, preventive measures and redress mechanism. The judgment is popularly known as Vishaka Judgment.<ref name="Vishaka 001">{{cite journal |url = http://indiankanoon.org/doc/1031794/ |title = Vishaka & Ors vs State Of Rajasthan & Ors on 13 August 1997 |author1=Manohar, SV |author2=Kirpal, BN |journal=Supreme Court of India |date=August 1997 |volume=241 |id = SCC Ref:(1997)6. SCC 241 : (1997 AIR SCW 3043) |url-status = dead |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120605101608/http://indiankanoon.org/doc/1031794/ |archive-date=5 June 2012 }}</ref> In April 2013, India enacted its own law on sexual harassment in the workplace—[[The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013]]. Almost 16 years after the Supreme Court's landmark guidelines on prevention of sexual harassment in the workplace (known as the "[[Vishaka Guidelines]]"), the Act has endorsed many of the guidelines, and is a step towards codifying gender equality. The Act is intended to include all women employees in its ambit, including those employed in the unorganized sector, as well as domestic workers. The Indian law does not permit the victim or complainant to take assistance of a legal professional in the inquiry, however, in Arti Devi Vs Jawaharlal Nehru University,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://indiankanoon.org/doc/195150471/|title=The Redressal of Public Grievances Rules, 1998|work=Indian Kanoon}}</ref> the High Court of Delhi permitted the complainant to avail the services of a counsel as her defence assistant.
The Act has identified sexual harassment as a violation of the fundamental rights of a woman to equality under articles 14 and 15 of the Constitution of India and her right to life and to live with dignity under article 21 of the Constitution; as well as the right to practice any profession or to carry on any occupation, trade or business which includes a right to a safe environment free from sexual harassment. The Act also states that the protection against sexual harassment and the right to work with dignity are universally recognized human rights by international conventions and instruments such as Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination against Women, which has been ratified on the 25th June, 1993 by the Government of India.<ref>[[The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013]]</ref>{{Circular reference|date=February 2020}}
The [[Criminal Law (Amendment) Act, 2013]] introduced changes to the [[Indian Penal Code]], making sexual harassment an expressed offense under Section 354 A, which is punishable up to three years of imprisonment and or with fine. The Amendment also introduced new sections making acts like disrobing a woman without consent, stalking and sexual acts by person in authority an offense.
====Israel==== The 1998 Israeli Sexual Harassment Law interprets sexual harassment broadly, and prohibits the behavior as a discriminatory practice, a restriction of liberty, an offense to human dignity, a violation of every person's right to elementary respect, and an infringement of the right to privacy. Additionally, the law prohibits intimidation or retaliation thus related to sexual harassment are defined by the law as "prejudicial treatment".<ref name="Kamir">{{cite journal | last1 = Kamir | first1 = Orit | title = Israel's 1998 Sexual Harassment Law: Prohibiting Sexual Harassment, Sexual Stalking, and Degradation Based on Sexual Orientation in the Workplace and in all Social Settings | url = http://sitemaker.umich.edu/Orit_Kamir/files/sexharas2.pdf | journal = International Journal of Discrimination and the Law | volume = 2005 | issue = 7 | pages = 315–336 | access-date = 2012-10-07 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151017132743/http://sitemaker.umich.edu/Orit_Kamir/files/sexharas2.pdf | archive-date = 2015-10-17 | url-status = dead }}</ref>
====Japan==== [[File:Chikan Sign.jpg|301x301px|thumb|SexPublic sign in [[Chiba, Chiba|Chiba, Japan]], warning of [[Chikan (body contact)|''chikan'']]]]
The Department of Labor received 11,289 consultations regarding sexual harassment (approximately 60% from female workers, 5% from male workers, and 35% from others) in 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gender.go.jp/about_danjo/whitepaper/h27/zentai/html/zuhyo/zuhyo01-04-14.html |title=都道府県労働局雇用均等室に寄せられた職場におけるセクシュアル・ハラスメントの相談件数 |publisher=内閣府 |language=ja |access-date=2022-08-03}}</ref> However, given the generally low rate of reported sexual offenders (about 10%), the [[Dark figure of crime|dark figure]] of sexual harassers is believed to be substantial, with 34.7% of full-time employees experiencing sexual harassment, according to the Japan Institute for Labor Policy and Training.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://apj.aidem.co.jp/current/detail/1352.html |title=妊娠等を理由とする不利益取扱い及びセクシュアルハラスメントに関する実態調査 |publisher=労働政策研究・研修機構 |language=ja |access-date=2022-08-03}}</ref>
It appeared most dramatically in Japanese discourse in 1989, when a court case in Fukuoka ruled in favor of a woman who had been subjected to the spreading of sexual rumors by a co-worker. When the case was first reported, it spawned a flurry of public interest: 10 books were published, including English-language feminist guidebooks to 'how not to harass women' texts for men.<ref name="Huen">{{cite journal |last1=Huen|first1 = Y. |title=Workplace Sexual Harassment in Japan: A Review of Combating Measures Taken |journal=Asian Survey |year=2007|volume=47|issue=5|pages=811–827 |doi = 10.1525/as.2007.47.5.811 }}</ref> Sekuhara was named 1989's 'Word of the Year'. The case was resolved in the victim's favor in 1992, awarding her about $13,000 in damages, the first sexual harassment lawsuit in Japanese history.<ref name="MacGregor">{{cite news |last = MacGregor |first = Hillary |title = In Japan, Many Men Just Don't Get It : Nation only got word for sexual harassment after '89 court case. |url = http://articles.latimes.com/1995-10-13/news/mn-56533_1_sexual-harassment/2 |newspaper = Los Angeles Times |access-date = 26 October 2015 |date = 13 October 1995 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160105082011/http://articles.latimes.com/1995-10-13/news/mn-56533_1_sexual-harassment/2 |archive-date = 5 January 2016 |url-status = live }}</ref> Laws then established two forms of sexual harassment: ''taika-gata'', in which rewards or penalties are explicitly linked to sexual acts, and ''kankyo-gata'', in which the environment is made unpleasant through sexual talk or jokes, touching, or hanging sexually explicit posters.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/koyou_roudou/koyoukintou/seisaku06/index.html#h2_free5 |title=職場におけるセクシュアルハラスメントについて |publisher=厚生労働省 |language=ja |access-date=2022-08-03}}</ref> This applies to everyone in an office, including customers.<ref name="Huen" />
====Malaysia==== {{main|Sexual harassment in Malaysia}}
In Malaysia, sexual harassment as defined by the [http://www.agc.gov.my/agcportal/uploads/files/Publications/LOM/EN/Act%20265%20-%20Employment%20Act%201955.pdf Employment Act 1955] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201111235552/http://www.agc.gov.my/agcportal/uploads/files/Publications/LOM/EN/Act%20265%20-%20Employment%20Act%201955.pdf |date=2020-11-11 }}, is "any unwanted conduct of a sexual nature, whether verbal, non-verbal, visual, gestural or physical, directed at a person which is offensive, humiliating or a threat to their well-being". The Act does not distinguish between male and female or employer and employee. As such, sexual harassment can be committed by a female against a male, or an employee against an employer.
Sexual harassment is common, and since 2010 trains on the Malaysian Railway have included pink-colored [[women-only passenger car|women-only cars]] as a means of cutting down on it.<ref name="buses">{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/40468372/ns/world_news-asia_pacific/t/women-only-buses-aim-halt-sex-harassment/|title=Women-only buses aim to halt sex harassment|work=NBC News|date=2 December 2010|access-date=9 June 2017}}</ref> There are also women-only buses in Kuala Lumpur since 2010.<ref name="buses" /> In 2011, the government launched a women-only taxi service in the greater Kuala Lumpur area.<ref name="taxis">{{cite web|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/11/27/179417.html|title=Malaysia launches women-only taxis, hoping to reduce number of rape and robbery cases|work=Agence France-Presse|publisher=Al Arabiya News|date=27 November 2011|access-date=9 June 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171004034930/http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/11/27/179417.html|archive-date=4 October 2017|url-status=dead|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The taxis have women drivers, and operate on an on-call basis.<ref name="taxis" />
==== New Zealand ==== In 2018, Statistics New Zealand published the Survey of Working Life findings, which queried employed individuals about their work schedules, employment circumstances, and level of job satisfaction and work-life balance. 9% of males and 14% of women reported having dealt with bullying, harassment, or discrimination at work in the preceding year.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Continued reports of sexual harassment, assault and bullying at work; steps towards change {{!}} New Zealand Family Violence Clearinghouse |url=https://nzfvc.org.nz/news/continued-reports-sexual-harassment-assault-and-bullying-work-steps-towards-change |access-date=2023-09-30 |website=nzfvc.org.nz}}</ref> Any invitation for sexual activity, whether direct or indirect, is considered sexual harassment according to the Employment Relations Act of 2000. The individual harassing the victim may be a boss, an employee, a volunteer, a coworker, an employer's representative, or even a customer, contractor, or supplier who is not an employee.<ref>{{Cite web |title=What is sexual harassment |url=https://www.employment.govt.nz/resolving-problems/types-of-problems/bullying-harassment-and-discrimination/sexual-harassment/what-is-sexual-harassment/ |access-date=2023-09-30 |website=Employment New Zealand |language=en-NZ}}</ref>
Health and Safety at Work Act 2015, the duties of PCBU (person undertaking a business or undertaking) responsibility according to the act 36, subpart 2, Duties of PCBU is
· “The provision and maintenance of a work environment that is without risks to health and safety”; and
· “The provision and maintenance of safe plant and structures”; and
· “The provision and maintenance of safe systems of work”; and
· “The safe use, handling, and storage of plants, substances, and structures”.<ref>{{Cite web |title=New Zealand legislation |url=https://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/2015/0070/latest/DLM5976894.html#DLM5976894 }}</ref>
As per the Employment Relations Act 2000, it is possible for you to file a personal grievance. A worker may file a personal grievance against their employer. You have 12 months from the date when the assault happened or became aware of your knowledge, whichever comes first.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Steps for workers to address sexual harassment |url=https://www.employment.govt.nz/resolving-problems/types-of-problems/bullying-harassment-and-discrimination/sexual-harassment/steps-for-workers-to-address-sexual-harassment/ |access-date=2023-09-30 |website=Employment New Zealand |language=en-NZ}}</ref>
Employment Relations (Extended Time for Personal Grievance for Sexual Harassment) Amendment Act 2023 and, section 54 amended states, an explanation in simple terms of the resources that are available for resolving issues with relationships at work, in relation to the 12-month period that must pass before filing a personal grievance under section 114(1) if the grievance relates to sexual harassment under section 103(1)(d).<ref>{{Cite web |title=New Zealand Legislation |url=https://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/2023/0028/latest/LMS577477.html |website=New Zealand Legislation}}</ref>
Human Rights Act 1993 under 62 sexual harassment states that, in the course of engaging in any of the activities covered by the provisions of subsection (3), it is illegal for anyone to ask another person for sexual relations, sexual contact, or any other type of sexual activity when doing so contains an implicit or overt guarantee of favorable treatment. During one's engagement in each of the areas where subsection (3) applies, it is forbidden for an individual to subject another individual to the conduct of the actions that follow:
(a) a conduct that is unwanted or offensive to that individual (regardless of whether that is communicated to the first-mentioned individual); and
(b) an act that is either repeated or of a significant nature as to negatively impact that individual in relation to any of the regions where subsection (3) applies.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Human rights act 1993 |url=https://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1993/0082/latest/DLM304651.html |website=New Zealand Legislation}}</ref>
==== Pakistan ==== Pakistan introduced the [[Protection Against Harassment of Women at the Workplace Act, 2010|''Protection Against Harassment of Women at the Workplace Act'']] in 2010. This law defines the act of harassment as. "[A]ny unwelcome sexual advance, request for sexual favors or other verbal or written communication or physical conduct of a sexual nature or sexually demeaning attitude, causing interference with work performance or creating an intimidating, hostile or offensive work environment, or the attempt to punish the complainant for refusal to such a request or is made a condition for employment." Pakistan adopted a Code of Conduct for Gender Justice in the Workplace that will deal with cases of sexual harassment. The [[Alliance Against Sexual Harassment]] (AASHA) announced they would be working with the committee{{Clarify|reason=What committee?|date=August 2021}} to establish guidelines for the proceedings. AASHA defines sexual harassment similarly to the United States.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aasha.org.pk/ |title=Alliance Against Sexual Harassment |publisher=AASHA |access-date=2012-10-07 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121025235625/http://www.aasha.org.pk/ |archive-date=2012-10-25 |url-status=live }}</ref>{{Full citation needed|date=February 2020}}
